metadata.case_name: A. V. Thomas and Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax

facts.text: The assessee, A. V. Thomas and Co. Ltd., Alleppey, incorporated in 1935, authorised by memorandum of association to promote and undertake formation of other companies, make investments and assist any company financially or otherwise.
Assessee had three directors: A. V. Thomas, S. Sankaranarayana Iyer, and J. Thomas.
Southern Agencies Ltd., Pondicherry, private limited company with directors A. V. Thomas, S. S. Natarajan, and C. S. Ramakrishnan Karayalar.
There was a mill in Pondicherry known as Rodier Textile Mills belonging to Anglo-French Textiles Ltd.
In 1948, Southern Agencies Ltd. took up promotion of Rodier Textile Mills Ltd., Pondicherry, to buy and develop Rodier Textile Mills.
Assessee financed Southern Agencies Ltd. by making over funds aggregating Rs. 6,05,071-8-6, not directly but at its instance by India Coffee and Tea Distributors Ltd., Madras.
Entry in assessee's books dated December 31, 1948, showed amount as advance for purchase of 6,000 shares of Rs. 100 each in Rodier Textile Mills Ltd.

Subscription list for Rodier Textile Mills Ltd. open from January 5 to January 20, 1949; no application for shares made on behalf of assessee; shares not acquired; public took no interest; project failed.
On September 1, 1950, assessee approved action of Mr. A. V. Thomas in making the advance.

On September 18, 1950, board of directors of assessee passed resolution that Rs. 6,00,000 be shown as advance for purchase of shares in Rodier Textile Mills Ltd. in formation and balance Rs. 5,072-8-5 under sundry advances due from promoters.
On December 7, 1951, Southern Agencies Ltd. paid back Rs. 2,00,000 received in full satisfaction.
As late as June 12, 1951, advance considered good and recoverable.
Balance Rs. 4,05,072-8-6 written off on December 31, 1951, close of assessee's year of account.
Claimed deduction of Rs. 4,05,072-8-6 in assessment year 1952-53 as bad debt written off, alternatively as expenditure not of capital nature under section 10(2)(xv).
Income-tax Officer, Alleppey, disallowed claim holding debt neither bad nor doubtful and write-off premature.

Appellate Assistant Commissioner upheld ITO on different ground: advance for purchasing shares, for acquisition of capital asset (control or goodwill for agency rights); loss capital nature; not allowable under section 10(2)(xv).

Tribunal upheld AAC on third ground: one object of assessee was promotion/financing but this advance not in normal course of business; actuated by personal motives; no previous business connection with Southern Agencies; common ownership of A.V. Thomas and S.S. Natarajan.

Tribunal refused reference; assessee applied to High Court of Kerala which directed reference on single question: Whether Tribunal correct in holding amount not admissible under section 10(2)(xi) or 10(2)(xv)? Answered against assessee; certified fit for Supreme Court appeal.

Ledger entries in assessee's books (annexures A-1 to A-3): December 1948, amounts paid towards purchase of shares; January 1, 1949 debit balance Rs. 6,05,071-8-5; by Dec 31, 1949 transferred Rs. 5,071-8-5 to sundry expenses, balance Rs. 6,00,000; 1950 closed by amount paid to Southern Agencies; 1951: Rs. 2,00,000 received Dec 7, Rs. 4,00,000 transferred for write-off Dec 31; Rs. 5,072-8-5 also written off.

On December 15, 1952, chairman of assessee stated in speech: 'advance was made to Southern Agencies Pondicherry Ltd. to acquire for us shares in Rodier Textile Mills Ltd. ... our company stood considerably to gain by securing their agency'.

legal_issues.text: Whether, on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the Tribunal was correct in holding that the amount of Rs. 4,05,071-8-6 claimed by the assessee as a deduction was not admissible either under section 10(2)(xi) or 10(2)(xv)?

petitioner_arguments.text: Advance in ordinary course of business as per memorandum objects to promote/finance companies; treat as trading loss under s.10(1), or bad debt u/s 10(2)(xi), or expenditure u/s 10(2)(xv); relied on ledger entries.

High Court wrong in requiring proof of past purchase/sale of agencies; object to apply for shares but did not, so remained advance in ordinary course; right to write off as bad debt when not returned.

respondent_arguments.text: Debt written off premature, neither bad nor doubtful.
Advance for purchase of shares, acquisition of capital asset (control/goodwill for agency); capital loss.
Not in normal course of business; personal motives; no previous connection; common directors.

court_reasoning.text: Question limited to s.10(2)(xi)/(xv); s.10(1) not raised properly before High Court.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Assessee should have requested High Court to frame question on whether material for Tribunal's finding of non-business transaction.

court_reasoning.text: Under s.10(2)(xv): capital expenditure for acquiring shares to gain agency; confirmed by chairman's speech; not expended in 1951 but 1948; not business to buy/sell agencies.
Under s.10(2)(xi): not a debt; advance for shares, not incidental to business; if good, would not swell taxable profits; changes in books to convert advance to debt; memorandum not conclusive.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Debt must be trading debt related to business; cited Curtis, Arunachalam, Abdullabhai, Badridas Daga.

holdings.text: Deduction not admissible under section 10(2)(xv) as expenditure of capital nature.
Deduction not admissible under section 10(2)(xi) as amount not a proper debt related to business.

precedents_cited.case_name: Curtis v. J. G. Oldfield Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Definition of bad debt: trading debt that would swell profits if good.

precedents_cited.case_name: Arunachalam Chettiar v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Bad debt must, if good, swell taxable profits; approved Rowlatt J.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Abdullabhai Abdulkadar
Badridas Daga v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Business debt springs from carrying on business, incidental; not any loss with connection.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Deduction claimed as business loss, bad debt, or revenue expenditure; reference under 66(2); allowances for bad debts and business expenditure.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; High Court correct in holding deduction not admissible under section 10(2)(xi) or 10(2)(xv).

key_quotes.text: "You are aware that an advance was made to the Southern Agencies Pondicherry Ltd. to acquire for us shares in Rodier Textile Mills Ltd. It was felt that ... our company stood considerably to gain by securing their agency for handling their goods."
key_quotes.speaker: petitioner
key_quotes.significance: Confirms intention to acquire capital asset via shares for agency business.

key_quotes.text: When the rule speaks of a bad debt it means a debt which is a debt that would have come into the balance-sheet as a trading debt ... and that it is bad.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines 'bad debt' under s.10(2)(xi) from Curtis v. Oldfield.

key_quotes.text: A debt in such cases is an outstanding which if recovered would have swelled the profits. It is not money handed over to someone for purchasing a thing which that person has failed to return even though no purchase was made.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains debt must relate to business, not mere advance.
